rev.comment: /* Necrophilia in literature */ william faulkner's "A Rose for Emily"
rev.diff:
Line 42: Line 42:
In Algernon Charles Swinburne's poem, "The Leper," the speaker is scribe who had long desired a woman in the royal house where he is employed. When she contracts leprosy, she is deserted by all others. The scribe then takes care of her, and has an arguably necrophilic relationship with her.
In Algernon Charles Swinburne's poem, "The Leper," the speaker is scribe who had long desired a woman in the royal house where he is employed. When she contracts leprosy, she is deserted by all others. The scribe then takes care of her, and has an arguably necrophilic relationship with her.
  +   +
Published in 1930, William Faulkner's "A Rose for Emily" tells the story of a lonely house ridden woman named Emily Grierson who deals with the strange circumstances of her father, the man she loves, and her secret world of necrophilia.
==Notable necrophiles==
==Notable necrophiles==
